text: Básicamente con el estetoscopio viene la idea de la ocultación, de poder escuchar los sonidos que produce el cuerpo, con el propósito de generar un diagnóstico. En este momento el estetoscopio funciona más como una herramienta de valoración primaria, pues porque hay un desarrollo tecnológico que permite tener muchos otros herramientas para diagnóstico, pero sin embargo, después de tanto tiempo sigue ahí vigente, porque ese es un componente muy importante en la manera en la que nosotros podemos utilizar nuestras habilidades de escucha en el diagnóstico. Bueno, adicionalmente ahora el desarrollo tecnológico ya no solo nos permite escuchar los sonidos que produce el cuerpo, sino también nos permite transformar otros datos en sonidos con el propósito de entenderlos mejor. Y aquí viene el concepto de sonificación. Básicamente la idea de la sonificación es transformar datos en sonidos con el propósito de transmitir información.

text: cuando se requiere la atención por alguna anomalía que se esté presentando. Por ejemplo, uno de los más conocidos es el pulso oxímetro. Este es muy conocido de productos audiovisuales. Básicamente, la idea del pulso oxímetro es que se emite un sonido de corta duración que está alineado con la frecuencia cardíaca. Cada vez que hay un latido, pues se produce un sonido de estos. El sonido, la frecuencia del sonido básicamente nos quiere dar algún tipo de información sobre el nivel de saturación de oxígeno, el nivel de oxígeno de la sangre. Entonces, si ese rango está en un rango normal, que está alrededor del 95% y 100%, pues el sonido tiene ciertas características. Sin embargo, si nos comenzamos a salir de ese rango, el sonido va a cambiar. Y el propósito de esto es transmitir información al porfuego del médico para que pueda atender, en este caso, la situación que se está presentando. Vamos a escuchar un sonido de pulsoxímetro para que tengamos una idea de cómo suena. Este es el pulsoxímetro que se utiliza en ánditos médicos. Listo, entonces, si ustedes escucharon el sonido, acá tenemos una representación de la forma de onda del sonido del pós-oxímetro, que efectivamente son sonidos de corta duración, que están alineados a la frecuencia carriaca.

author: PyCon Colombia
text: So Epifact should not have done this. They should have used their domain that people trust to announce a breach. author: PyCon Colombia
text: a lot of experience doing this. So let's talk a little bit about the future of Internet archiving. We have little tools that run on our laptops, we have bigger tools that run on centralized companies like archive.org. But is that really the best way to archive most of the internet? Are the central archives the ones that survive through the ages? What happened to the Library of Alexandria? That was a big central archive. It was set on fire and we lost all of those records. What happened to all of the priests that collected manuscripts over thousands of years? Well, they got attacked because another religion wanted to burn their church down. So a lot of the archives that we have over millennia turn out to be the little scraps

title: Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020

author: PyCon Colombia
text: of paper that were just in the corner of someone's room or in a notebook that got put away in

author: PyCon Colombia
text: a chest of drawers.

author: PyCon Colombia
text: It's the distributed archives that are spread out everywhere.

title: Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020 [LZ7TNQjG74g].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: The little bits that we all store individually will survive through the ages.

title: Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020 [LZ7TNQjG74g].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And the big ones will too, but it's nice to have redundancy. Another thing is that a central authority like archive.org doesn't actually have the capacity to archive the entire internet. They don't have nearly enough hard drives. But if we each archive the small bits of the internet that we care about on our own hard drives, then together we'll cover a much larger portion of the internet than any central organization can.

title: Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020 [LZ7TNQjG74g].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: So, an interesting thing happens when you start to archive a lot of the internet and spread it out over all of our computers.

title: Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Nick Sweeting - Archiving the Internet Before it All Rots Away  - PyCon Colombia 2020 [LZ7TNQjG74g].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: People start to think, why should I pay for hosting? If I publish something, it's going to be archived in 20 different places, and then they can just visit it there. Why should I even have to host my own website? So in 20 years, we might see an interesting effect where, as more content gets mirrored automatically around the internet, people don't really bother with hosting their own versions anymore. It sort of naturally becomes distributed because people start to rely on the fact that the internet will remember. So let's think back to the Equifax incident. And remember the the ethical dilemmas of cloning content. Think about what happens if we clone the entire internet and it were to last forever, and everything you did on the internet would be remembered forever with no way to delete it. Is that a good thing? Is that something we really want? Maybe part of what makes the internet beautiful is that people do things that they know they wouldn't otherwise do if it would be remembered forever. You might not post a risky blog article. You might not,

text: IIPC is sort of an overarching organization that connects a lot of the individual communities. And there are many fantastic conferences and tools and blog articles and people to follow. And we've collected it all in this wiki for you. So I'll post the link at the end on the final slide and my slides will be available on GitHub. I highly recommend checking out this wiki, even if you never run any web archiving tools yourself. So a final note to end on is that it's actually very easy to archive Wikipedia and Ted Talks and Project Gutenberg. They're all available freely and you're allowed to re-host them. So I created some documentation called Wikipedia Mirror on GitHub that walks you through re-hosting all of Wikipedia. So on my server at home I have the entire English Wikipedia, Project Gutenberg, all of Stack Overflow, and the Chinese Wikipedia. And all together it's only about 200 gigabytes. And the awesome thing is that the English Wikipedia archive is only 80 gigabytes for 6 million articles and images. All of the images in all of Wikipedia are offline on my server. It's incredible. So if everyone does this, if everyone works on re-hosting Wikipedia, it won't go down as often.

Bueno pues nosotros hemos estado muy felices con el evento, la verdad es que superó en gran media nuestras expectativas. Desde el inicio todo el tema de invitación, de logística, de coordinación, de poder ser patrocinadores fue muy bueno. Todas las personas estuvieron muy atentas y muy pendientes de que todo pasara de la mejor manera y creo que se lograron las expectativas. En cuanto a ser patrocinadores, claro que sí, nos gustaría, como te dije, nuestro objetivo es poder darnos a conocer a la comunidad, que las personas nos conozcan, conozcan que somos una empresa especializada en reclutamiento y staff del sector, y que podemos cumplir e impactar positivamente a las necesidades que están surgiendo. text: because I've tried myself to contribute sometimes

author: PyCon Colombia
text: to open source projects.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020

author: PyCon Colombia
text: I do that in a projects. I do that sometimes. I do that. So I'm amazed about how people like you manage to work full time and still contribute to this amazing project. How do you achieve that? What's your secret? I mean, it's hard. Like, I know no one thinks about it, right? There's a reason that turnover and burnout is a big problem in open source, because it is hard to do a full time job and then go and do Django. I have been very fortunate that Evenry gives me some time each week to work on Django. That helps a lot. It's about a day a week, roughly. But many people do it without that. And I did it without it for many years. The key thing is, first of all, to not pressure yourself.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: In some ways, open source can feel like a guilt driven development, where you feel like the community depends on you.

path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You've got to do this thing and that just increases the burnout, right? That just makes it worse.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You've got to step back and appreciate that what you're doing is valuable, even if it's a small change, right? Even small steps improve those things. And also it just gets like finer time, like I'm lucky that for me programming

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: is fun still, right? Like when I'm in the right mood, that's not all the time, but like in the

author: PyCon Colombia
text: right mood I'll go, I'll put some music on, I'll open up my editor and I will try and pry open like

text: the ASIC problem, the migrations problem, just think it through,

author: PyCon Colombia
text: and then try and make it work. But honestly, at the end of the day, the main thing that

path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: drives me is people coming to me and telling me that they love my work and the benefit

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: from it. It is those moments at conferences when someone comes up to me and says, oh,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: by the way, we've used your work, it's amazing. Like, thank you so much. Like, as an open source maintainer, mostly what you see are the support

path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: emails, the bug emails. I get a very precious few thank you emails every year, and they are

text: incredible. I treasure them. Conferences are much better for that. One reason I come to many of them.

path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But just getting that feedback and knowing that what you're doing is helping real people, that goes a long way. And there are many

path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: people out there who never get that feedback. If you're watching this, I encourage you like,

author: PyCon Colombia
text: please email the projects you use and thank them, because they will love it. Like, they never get

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: told that and it will help them that much out of it. Like open source is about that feeling.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Some of you don't capture it. Like that's what keeps me going. That's why I occasionally sacrifice

author: PyCon Colombia
text: a Saturday or a weeknight to work on Django because I believe in it. I believe it helps us as

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: engineers, right, as an industry, helps me push us forward. Yeah, that's really cool. And speaking

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: about burnout, do you have any piece of advice for the people in our community feeling worked out?

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I mean, my main thing to say is it happens, right? Like, you've got to believe that it's a thing, it's not just you, there are ways of dealing with it, and the number one way of dealing with it is to stop.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, so many people just try and push through, or ignore it, or try and tough up, That's not the right approach. You've got to accept it and work with yourself. And sometimes that means walking away from a thing you love, right? Like sometimes it means take it like I took six months away from migrations. And the same with channels as well because I knew that I was getting close to burnout. I've been through it several times. I know the signs of it. And I was like, okay, before I get too far, I'm going to, I know the channel, I said, ultimately, I said, if no one steps up by the end of January, and this was like maybe last year or the year before, I'm gonna have to put this into maintenance mode, like I cannot maintain it anymore. As one Carlson very graciously stepped in moments and other people as well. But the key thing is like, no person is an island. And like to realize that like, there's a port network is what helps. Like there's no easy trick to burn out, right? It's a it's a case of what you want to do misaligning with what you can do, be it at work, be it in your personal life, like often, having a bad time at work, you can bring it home and it can affect your open source work as well. Like don't look at one place to fix it. Yeah, like, and it was like, burnout can be a sign of other

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: problems too, right? Like, I would always say like, if you have, if you feel bad overall, like,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you can go and talk to a therapist. I've done that in the past, like they are very effective

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: people at talking you through your even one or two sessions, they can talk you through your own

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: problems, they can teach you how to deal with them

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: as well so like it's a there's no one trick right for me it's all like what I

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: do now is I make sure that I do my work in smaller chunks that I can like

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: finish and feel good about that's kind of one trick I have myself so like for

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: example the async views patch in theango, I could have put a whole lot

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: more things into that patch, but I didn't one to avoid burnout and two, because I've written that

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: list down, other people can try doing it and trying to learn how to patch Django as part of that,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: right? Like understanding that other people can come along and help you. And like, if you just

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: give them work, they will take it and learn from it. That's another important lesson I've really, really valued.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Nice. And with all the things you've been through working in the open source, like how's the concept of the Python community for you have evolved or changed during the years?

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: have evolved or changed during the years? I mean, in many ways, the Python community is why I'm still here, right? I often joke that Python is a very decent language for everything, right? Which

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it is, but it's honestly, it is that ability to welcome newcomers, to always be there, to understand

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the difficult challenges. The community is what makes this language. So many other languages that look promising, I look closer when their community is

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: toxic or is not supportive. I'm like, I just don't want that. So, the Python community is everything

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: to me. If I took a job that didn't write Python, I'd still come to conferences. That is how

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: importantly I value the community. A lot of my friends are in the community as well. I know people who have left Python who still come to conferences in that sense. I think in many ways it's because Python represents this greater goal of what it is to be a software engineer or computer scientist or any one of those things. We try and help each other, we try and understand, we know the compromise exists, we know the trade-offs exist. We're open about that. We try and bring people in to the community who are usually excluded. All those things I really treasure. I honestly hope that we can affect programming as a whole. In many ways, Python is one of the top languages. We're doing that. We're setting the trend. I want to keep doing that. I think Python is incredibly valuable. And Django as well. The

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Django community is this subsection of Python that is somehow, in some ways, even better. And I'm

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: not saying the other ones are bad, but the Django community especially is so friendly and so welcoming.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I would probably go to Django conferences as long as I could, even if I went to go and write another framework. That's just how much I value them as well. We talk about burnout, right? It's a community that undoes my burnout. It's they who step in to help, they who reassure me, who understand how things are going. When I have a difficult issue, I'll just ask some people I know. They might say, it's difficult, which is great, it reaffirms that it's pretty hard. They might give me an answer. They might go, oh, I'm not sure. Come away and come back a day later. But all of those things are really valuable. And that you're also a pilot, right? Yes. And I know you've talked about this in a conference in the tall UK, but what are one of the most useful things you got from that board into the programming world that really helped you? Yeah, being a pilot is fascinating, right? So I got into it, I'd say by accident, I didn't really like it. My mother bought me my first flying lessons at present for a birthday many years ago and I was hooked from that first lesson basically. And what's interesting is that being a pilot is mostly about preparing for failure, right? Like it's about like, my training was about 10 hours of actually learning to fly properly, about 40 hours of recovering from engine failures or like takeoff failures or like just emergency procedures in general. And that's true as you go to commercial pilots as well. Most of their training is not flying the aircraft in nice weather. It's what to do if any one of these number of problems occur. And I think that's a really interesting perspective. I brought it through some of my talks as you said, like we have taken aviation and made it one of the safest forms of transport on Earth.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like say it's safer than walking, it's safer than cycling, it's safer than cars. I think trains are the only thing safer. And they're on two rails and go one direction, right? It's ridiculously different comparison. And I think part of that's

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the mentality, right? Pilots, at least modern pilots, have learned to operate with each other,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: to understand their risks. Like you're taught as a pilot that risk is not a thing you can run away

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: from. You have to always embrace the risk and understand it. You never take off in a flight

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: not knowing the risks. You analyze it and you make a go or no-go call. And to me that philosophy is really important because a lot of developers just bury their heads in the sand and don't look at risk.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: They just think, oh, it might happen, it might not. If you look at the risk and analyze it, it becomes a lot less scary. You can understand the causes of failure. And that kind of approach, I think, really sits well with me. Also, like, BiggerPilot's very analytical and process-oriented, right?

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, it's all checklists, it's all doing things properly.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, if you want to respond to, like, a site being down as, like, an operational incident,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you should probably run, like, a cockpit crew runs when the engine goes out, right?

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Because, like, they have refined that experience so well over so many years, and even including the human factor.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: They realized in the late 80s, early 90s, that one of the biggest problems is you have to trust each other in the cockpit.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You have to make sure that if the first officer disagrees with the captain, they talk about it.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Because a few flights crashed, but they didn't talk about it.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: To me, it shows

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: not only that it's not just about technology, it's also about communication. That whole

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: package to me represents the thing we do, which is building and operating these super

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: complex systems. That's kind of what pilots do as well. They build them, but they do something,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: operate them. I think we can learn from that a lot. Yeah, that's really interesting.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And those are all the questions.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But on behalf of the whole Colombian fighting community,

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I want to thank you for being here with us.

title: Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Andrew Godwin - PyCon Colombia 2020 [0ZNMZdFk_WY].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Because I know it's not easy to get some of your time

author: PyCon Colombia
text: usé PiMavlink, que es la librería que se encarga de gestionar todos los mensajes de Mavlink, es simplemente otra especie de idioma, es un protocolo para los drones, PiSerial para acceder a los sensores de toda la información que yo necesite a través de serial, Redis para crear una pila y estar ahí almacenando los mensajes que necesito enviar. text: Normalmente, bueno, por accidente. Normalmente, uno cuando empieza a construir el primer producto, empieza, no quiere hacer algo complejo, quiere empezar por algo que sea fácil de poner en producción, rápido, para validar una idea. De esta manera, es que empezamos a hacer un monolito. En la arquitectura el monolito es construcción sobre un solo material. Se hace una analogía cuando es el diseño de software que tiene que ver con un stack tecnológico. Elegimos un stack tecnológico y construimos sobre ese stack. ¿Qué quiere decir? Elegimos Python, Django, MySQL y alguna cola de mensajes. Esto para ir a producción esástico. Vamos rápido, pero empiezan a ocurrir problemas. Cuando crece, son miles y miles de líneas de códigos, y estas líneas de código se vuelven complejas, hay una interdependencia. Si queremos modificar una parte, seguramente tengamos que tocar otra parte del código o romper cosas, los tests son gigantescos. Y empezamos encontrarnos con que viene el manuel y nos dice che, ahora queremos hacer machine learning y nosotros estamos trabajando en Go, por ejemplo. Y sabemos que integrar algo de Python dentro de un monolito en Go es muy complicado. Entonces, por estos motivos es que las compañías cuando crecen y empiezan a hacer software mucho más complejo, empiezan a tomar decisiones de separar este monolito en pequeñas piezas.

Es un protocolo que se monta sobre un montón de cosas. En particular la red. Entonces, por ejemplo, que yo quiero en mi aplicación que calcula el tiempo de envío de un paquete, típicamente voy a depender de otros servicios. Voy a depender de servicios externos, porque yo voy a querer calcular para determinado usuario y determinado producto, bueno, cuánto tarde ese producto en llegar a su casa, entonces yo voy a tener que pedirle a la API de direcciones de usuarios que me diga las direcciones de mi usuario y le voy a querer pedir a otro endpoint que es la información de los vores, que me da información y después a la información de las direcciones de los vendedores.

text: Posiblemente, a un mismo servicio yo le quiero pegar muchas veces este código cada vez que llega un request ustedes entrarán a Mercado Libre, al Marketplace, entrarán a ver un item y en algún momento les dice, por ejemplo, cuánto va a tardar en llegar aproximadamente el sistema a su casa. Eso significa que con cada request que llega a Mercado Libre, este código se ejecuta. Y en Mercado Libre tenemos cientos de miles de requests por min minuto y significa que este endpoint se va a llamar cientos de miles de veces por minuto. Entonces estas llamadas, mi micro servicio, le va a estar pegando a los otros micro servicios de una manera exponencial con respecto al tráfico que recibo. Entonces, qué pasa cada vez que yo le pego a otro microservicio? Esto que en mi computadora se ve mejor. Esto tiene que ver más o menos con la explicación del protocolo TCP, la capa de red. ¿Qué pasa cuando yo le envío desde mi cliente a un mensaje al servidor? Se establece una comunicación a nivel red donde primero hay que ir al DNS para ver cuál es la IP del servidor al que tiene que llegar, porque yo le digo una URL, una string, entonces da de esa IP, tengo que empezar a mandar ciertos mensajes de conexión a ese otro servidor, entonces esos son un montón de mensajes entre la máquina origen y la máquina destino. Le mando un mensaje para que se conecta y una vez que se conecta tiene que haber, si estoy en un esquema de SSL o de seguridad, hay todo un intercambio de protocolos asociados a que pueden

author: PyCon Colombia
text: Y nos encontramos que si bien no es tan amigable, digamos, acá uno no puede utilizar como hacía con request de no hacer una sesión, acá realmente hay que hacer un pull. Lo Session de request en el fondo hace un pull de URLib3. Hay que ser más explícito en los parámetros. No es tan que los adivine más quicamente. Igual son dos parámetros nomás. Uno dice a cuántos dominios diferentes va a mantener una conexión. Por ejemplo, si me conecto a cinco microservicios, el número de pull es cinco. Y el max size, que está ahí como diez, es la cantidad de hilos que vamos a tener abiertos por cada pool. Entonces, si estamos trabajando con Unicore o WSGI y estamos haciendo threading y vamos a poner 10 hilos, sabemos que ahí tenemos que poner un número 10 o más. Esto no es un número duro, no es que si de repente hay más hilos corriendo y se establecen más conexiones, no nos va a permitir, lo que va a pasar, que cuando se cumple un timeout va a ir eliminando conexiones y siempre va a dejar 10 establecidas. Y las otras se van a tener que establecer cuando se inician.

author: PyCon Colombia
text: But let's talk about, it interests me a little bit. So, as you've heard, I'm Andrew Godwin. I am perhaps most well known for working on Django.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: A long part of that time was doing Django migrations. I spent about eight years battling MySQL and Postgres and

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: SQLite to get those working. And then recently I've been working on channels and async in

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Django. In fact, about a week ago, I landed the I got the patch done for full async support

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: in Django views. So that's very exciting and coming in the next version. But I'm not going

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: to talk about Django too much today.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I'm gonna talk about some other things.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: In particular, my job at the moment

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: is principal engineer at Eventbrite.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I want to talk about that particular word, engineer.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I call myself an engineer.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I have done for most of the time I've been working.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: My very first job had that in its title. But what does that mean? At least in English, engineer applies to pretty much everything mechanical, right? Like people who make airplanes, people who make bridges, people who make things in the real world. How do we relate to them? In particular, what is confusing is I went to university and there I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied computer science. I studied, I went to university, and there I studied computer science, which is a different kind of thing. In fact, I almost didn't go to study that. I almost went to study physics. And I went to the university, I toured around it, it was Oxford, back in England, and the physics department was very lovely, I enjoyed my

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: time there, it looked very difficult, I was like, this looks a bit hard, I went to the computer science

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: department and I was like, oh this looks much more familiar, I already know programming, how hard can it be?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I was unfortunately very mistaken, programming is not computer science. Anyone who tells you that is perhaps

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: not really aware of the differences. There is programming in computer science, that's

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: true, but they're two quite different disciplines. And so I want to kind of talk through that

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: journey for me and how I view things now and then how it applies to how we develop software and how I still develop software. One of my favorite quotes is by Edgar Dijkstra. Dijkstra, if those who aren't aware, invented the basic and modern graph traversal algorithm that your phone uses to find places when it's doing routes. I love this quote because it says something very simple. Computer science is no more about computers than astronomy is about telescopes.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: What he's trying to say here is that it's not really about the things you run the programs on.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Computer science is this wonderful world of pure programs. The computers are almost an annoying distraction in some cases.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: One of the things I discovered at university was that computer

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: science is quite what I would call idealistic in English. It almost ignores the real world

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and goes beyond into the virtual world. It's one of the few places you can think about

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: things in a purely abstract theoretical sense. There's a good reason at Oxford Computer Science is part

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of the mathematics department. They're kind of the same thing. I didn't really appreciate mathematics

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: when I was in school because it's all addition and subtraction and boring things like that.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I got to university and was like, oh, mathematics is much more interesting. There's proof, there's

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: logic, there's linear algebra, there's all these things they sort of, at least back in England, they just don't give you when you're a young child. And you get to university and realise that mathematics is totally different from the stuff you thought it was. There's no calculators really needed. And one of the things about computer science and its idealism is that we have this simple idea of what we can compute, what is possible.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You may have heard the phrase Turing complete. This refers to an idea put forth by the great

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Alan Turing of basically a theoretical computer. I'm not going to go into too much detail about

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: that computer. It basically has some memory and a big infinite tape. The key thing is,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it's a really silly design

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: for a computer if you were to build it now. But the wonderful thing is it's

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: effectively the same as any other computer. If you can run it on a touring

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: machine it's a full program. That means it is computable by any modern computer.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You can reduce anything currently down to that one thing. You may have seen

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: games like Minecraft where people build whole computers in Minecraft. That's because Minecraft is, as a game, touring complete. It has enough memory and state that you can build arbitrary things in it. In theory, given enough time, you could build Minecraft in Minecraft. It just wouldn't run very well. It'd be very slow. And so computer science is this wonderful world of proving things are possible.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: There is part about speed, and that's important too,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: but it's mostly about taking a problem and showing like, is it equivalent?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Is it the same? Can we do this on a normal computer?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Can we do this in what's called polynomial time? And that really appealed to me.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: The problem though is when you go in, like,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the first six months are fantastic and idealistic, and then you try and write stuff. And as an example,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I want to talk about sorting. Sorting or ordering things is one of the most popular problems in

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: computer science. Everyone knows that it has to be done in a certain amount of time, which we say

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: in O notation is O n log n. Now, O notation is fun because O notation completely ignores

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: any actual time factor. It's just a factor of how much it grows with the size of the

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: list. And in the real world, it's maybe not as useful as it might seem. As an example, here I have a sorting function implemented entirely in Python sleep.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You feed it a list of numbers.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It launches that many different coroutines in Python.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: They all sleep for the right number of seconds.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And at the end, you get a sorted list.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: There is no actual sorting involved, but it does still produce a sorted list. There is no actual sorting involved, but it does still position a sorted list. If you ask someone what kind of time factor this runs in, you get a wonderful puzzled look of, first of all, like, well, why are you doing this? Like, what's wrong with you? What's happening here? Then they suddenly go, well, it's probably a length of the list. Eventually, you get someone, they come like, you can't really reason about this.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You shouldn't do this.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It's a ridiculous idea.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: If not only because it is still sorting, it's relying on Python's code in relation which

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: sorts things numerically in time.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But it's an interesting idea of like code is never quite the same in the real world

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: as you'd want it to be.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It's not quite as clean, should we say.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: So one of the other fun things and thing I truly love about computer science is proof. If you've

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: ever worked with logic systems or algebras, you will know this idea like you can have an idea,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: a conjecture, as we say in English, And you can take that and a set of rules,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and you can work down and prove that what you have is correct.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now, this works for basic logic and basic ideas,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: but it also works for entire programs.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: My tutor at university, his department,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: was basically about proving things were correct.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: They, at one point, had a Java compiler that could prove, given a few days, that a basic Java program was correct.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now, the problem here is, Python is maybe not the best language for this. So here is a very simple program.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I would like to prove, ideally, that this program is correct. Now for that I need a specification. My specification is it returns true for the number two and false for everything else. Now you think that was simple and indeed if Python was a normal reasonable language, this would be simple to prove. We could do it by what's called induction or a few other things or different things. However Python is quite fun. You can do

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: things like this in Python where you can reassign true to false and not only just true become false

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: but somehow true equals false is true but I'm not sure if that's true or false. It's a very puzzling

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: thing. Thankfully Python 3 has fixed this. I can no longer scare new programmers at work with this particular problem.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But it's still fun. You can still do things like this in Python 3 if you're in the C layer.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, you can change what strings mean, you can change what integers are, it's very fun.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And so Python isn't really the best language for proving things. We'll get to what it's good for later.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But I want to show you what proof languages look like.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And as many of you know, I work on asynchronous programs. Asynchronous programming is very,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: very difficult. It's just because concurrent programming is difficult. Threads, coroutines,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: separate processes, these are all difficult things to think about. One of the things that really helps me think about these things is a proof language called

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: CSP.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: CSP looks ridiculous, I'll go on you, but what it's about is about proving how things

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: run concurrently.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It's a language for proving sequential things.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: In fact, CSP, the name means concurrent sequential processes.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: That's kind of where it came from. Using CSP,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you can model things like a vending machine or basic states. You can prove they deadlock,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: or they livelock. You can do all the basic reasoning about a distributed or concurrent

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: machine. In fact, if you are doing a big kind of annoying piece of hardware or project,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it's maybe not what you choose initially, but you can sit down and model things in this,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020

author: PyCon Colombia
