path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: SSD and leave it on a shelf can it keep data? And when or how often does quantum tunneling, which is literally a quantum effect of electrons vanishing and going through material by themselves, affect CPU It is way, way more common than you think it is.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like this laptop, in the time since I wrote this talk, has had four or five different bits flipped somewhere in it.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now, I've got to hope those bits are not in the talk slides, otherwise it's going to go very wrong very quickly.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But it's really common. In fact, the research for this comes from research by Boeing,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: when they're researching

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the number of errors that happened in their aircraft on the ground.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: They're like, oh, it turns out that there's so many bits in a computer, there's so many

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: cosmic rays, and they happen more often than you think, that one of them is going to get

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: flipped.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now, this is fine if it's like a picture or if it's something boring.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: If this is your bank account and your bank's computer, load your bank account into memory, and then just before it reads it, Cosmic Ray comes in and flips the one to a zero, you've got no money anymore. Like that's the thing you've got to prevent, right? Thankfully, we have what's called ECC RAM, Error Checking RAM, which finds and fixes these kind of things. But most of your laptops do not have that RAM. It's more expensive. And so most of you,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: without even knowing it, in the last couple of days have had some small piece of memory corrupted by a cosmic ray.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Let's just hope it wasn't important, eh?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: SSDs on a shelf, they last three weeks to a year.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Never use SSDs for backup. Now, SSDs, if you're not aware, the modern solid-state hard drives,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: they trap electrons in a kind of like a weird quantum cell, which the charge level is how much

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the data is. It's amazing science, it's fantastic. The read speeds and write speeds are great, and the

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: trade-off is they just don't last very long without power.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Enterprise-level SSDs, the ones you find in servers, they only last three weeks.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Ones like this laptop I have here, this is like a normal consumer one, that will last more like a year.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But of course, this gets worse as it gets hotter.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: If you have an SSD in 50 degrees Celsius, it will last about a day.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, the heat energy makes those electrons decay much faster.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And so I've seen people go and like, it's great, I have cheap SSDs, I use them for backup

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and put them in a big storage box.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I'm like, what are you doing?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like you're going to get back in two years, they're all going to be basically corrupted.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like the bits are going to be flipped everywhere.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: So you've got to think of this kind of stuff.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Ironically, hard drives, the good old spinning metal kind, they last for much, much longer. And so if you're doing backup, you still want hard drives for that reason.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Quantum tunneling, by the way, is a continuous effect. Modern CPUs just deal with quantum tunneling all the time. At some point, CPUs got so small, engineers are like, that's weird. There's like current leaking to the wrong side of the transistors, what's going on? And they found out that quantum tunneling

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: was just happening continuously. Thankfully, we can mostly ignore it, it mostly is just

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: extra heat energy or like the wrong kind of charge. As long as it's not too small, we

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: can deal with it, but like, if you are designing CPUs these days, quantum tunneling is a very active part of your job,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: which people don't seem to appreciate very much. What I want to underline here is that this is just

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: some of the things that go wrong. There's many, many more things than this, but you have to always

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: be prepared for that kind of failure. You have to design for the cosmic ray hitting your computer,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: for something going wrong.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: My favorite example that I love using in interviews or with new engineers and sort of mentoring

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: them is networking.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now people often assume, okay, the network is either up or the network is down, which

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: is already a bad assumption because, like, the real world is not that simple.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: The real world is the network is going to be like up and then 10 seconds slow and then one

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: second and some reason go by Australia and then come back again and eventually it'll be the right

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: speed and everything be in the wrong order. And like when you describe this people like, wait,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: networks can not be up or down, they can be slow. This is a common problem. And so you have to

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: design not just for simple failure, like the network being down, but for complex failure.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, well, the network is up, but it's four seconds to the next server, and it's dropping

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: half my packets.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: What do I do?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like a very stupid dumb program would simply go, well, the network's up, this thing says,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it's definitely up, I'm going to keep sending things, and it would probably crash.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And so if you design for failure and design for the worst case, when these things don't happen, you'll be very happy and can have a lovely coffee. When they do happen, you can be like, oh, well, it's bad, but it's designed for it. There's a idea called crash first software, where you build software designed to like, if you just turn off computer, it's perfectly fine. The being, if it can survive that, then it can survive being shut down normally.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like the worst thing that's happened is like you'll lose power all of a sudden.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like it happened at my house last weekend, we lost power for three hours, but everything

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: was fine.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It was designed to deal with that kind of thing.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And this kind of ties into how we think about software.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Now again, when you are taught programming, you're taught this wonderful

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: idea of like, you have a nice file of lines, the computer goes from the top of the file to the bottom

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of the file. It's very simple. Like it runs each line in order, it's easy to think about, there's a

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: problem, you can work out what line it's on and work that all out. Now that's great, that is how basic

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: programs used to work. If you go and write basic, that's fantastic.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And even simple Python, it works great. But there's a sort of a mountain to go over, like,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: from there to the real world. If you write code like this, you know, some basic asynchronous Python,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Python does not guarantee those two functions will run in order. I wanted to disable the alarm first

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and open the door. There's no guarantee of that at all. It might just run open door first,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: wait five seconds, run disable the alarm. It might not run either of them. It might

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: run them exactly at the same time in a weird race condition way. And this means that if

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: think about just this one example, modern programs are incredibly complicated.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Think of just the most basic big program you've written.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Think of just like what Django is, right?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Django is quite a simple framework in some respects, but it's ridiculously complicated.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: It has so many moving parts, no one Django core developer understands how the whole thing

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: works.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like I know some pieces, like,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Russ knows some pieces, and so on. But, like, we often have to ask each other, well, I don't know

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: how that thing works. Who does? And we sort of work out, oh, well, I think this person knows about

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: that. We go and ask them, oh, do you know about this? They're like, yes, I know about this. Please

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: ask me questions. Some people don't want to know about things, but they're the last person left. And then there are a few areas where no one knows about anymore.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: For example, doing the Django Async views work, all the code I was changing was written about nine or ten years ago.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I literally commented on that from like, nine years ago, Jacob wrote this. I asked him, he's like, I've forgotten that. I forgot that like six years ago, like I have no idea what this does at all.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And so I'm just going through there, like I'm the only person now who knows how half that stuff works basically because I've been through it recently.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like that's part of software. I often jokingly call it software archaeology. Your job is to go through old software and try and work, well, what was this person trying to do? Was this a ritual? Like, what kind of, what was happening here?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And eventually you work it out.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And that's kind of part of being a lead programmer too,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: is like, everyone always forgets software,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you gotta keep going.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: My Django itself has about a quarter of a million

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: lines of code.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: That seems like quite a lot, and trust me,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it's quite a lot when you're trying to check it out

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: over a hotel network here in Medellin.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But it's, you know, it's not too bad. You

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: can still think about it. I kind of know where everything is. If you ask me where a particular

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: piece of Django was, I'd kind of know roughly where to look and probably know about 10%

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of how it worked. Async is only an extra few thousand lines of code too, which is kind

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of why I'm happy about it. Like, could have been, you know, taking half this code, rewriting it, but we sort of squeezed it in so it wasn't too bad. Let's compare that with like actual real-world engineering. The largest passenger plane in the world is the two-floor Airbus A380. I love the A380, it's a great plane. It's ridiculous to go into a plane and see how big that thing is like you see it next to a normal plane, it's like a tiny toy, it's fun, but it has four million individual

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: parts like rivets, screws, computer chips, panels, what have you, hydraulic aviators.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: That seems like a lot of pieces right, like somebody, well not one person again, a lot of pieces, right? Like somebody, well, not one person, again, a group of engineers spent 10, 20 years carefully designing every part of the aircraft. But if you ask them,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: do you know about how the toilets work? I don't know. No, like Bill, he's a toilet guy. He

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: knows how the toilets work. I just know how the lights work. Like that's kind of how these

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: jobs are done. And that seems like a lot. And then you go to big software. Like how software works in the modern world. You think a plane is complicated? A modern car has a hundred million lines of code in it. A normal car. Just like a normal car you can buy from anywhere. Like we have so much software now just in a normal car, it's this complicated. Let's look at what a plane is. Like any big piece of like software on the internet has a few million lines, like Eventbrite has a few million lines of code, right? No one can understand that much. Not only like this is a hundred million lines of code, it runs in a hundred different chips. Can you imagine trying to debug that? Like how do you even start? What's the traceback look like? Is it three miles long? How does that work? So you run into this problem of like, software is changing the world. As software engineers, we are basically shaping the modern world. We dictate what happens. But we have this problem that we just can't understand it. If you, well, when you start out programming, at least I did, I felt powerful. I was like, I am like a god, right? Like I can control this. I understand the whole program. I understand exactly every single piece of it works. And for me, the difficult part was going from that to a big project. Going from a junior to a senior engineer, for me, was mostly learning to let go and not be able to understand everything anymore.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Because you just can't do it. You have to learn to just let that piece go. It's like how do you do that?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Especially if you're still earlier on in your career, haven't done this yet, like how do you handle

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: letting go and forgetting about pieces? And the way I approach it at at least, is a handy three-step process. Abstract, verify, and forget. Now, what do I mean by that?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: So, I think you already all do this and don't realize it, but basically, it is, first of all, you abstract something.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You take a problem, and either you write it yourself, you give it to a team, but you define a contract. You say, okay, this Python module will take in an image and return me its primary color. How it does that, I don't care about it. All I care about is that it takes in an image and gives me the biggest color in that image. That's your contract. You set that and you trust in it. And to make sure you can trust in it, you verify. You write tests. You say, okay, here are a hundred images. We've verified. These are the right background colors for them. We test the module. We make sure it does the right thing.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And once you've got this, you can then forget about it. You can say, okay, I have a contract and the contract is simple. I can understand and keep the contract in my mind at all times.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And the contract is simple. I can understand and keep the contract in my mind at all times. Like, you know, oh, this module, I give it an event and it returns me how much it costs in fees and taxes. I can understand that. I can verify it because I know not only their tests, but in case of, there's a whole team who just work on that particular, like Dan and Mendoza and Argentina, there's a whole team just work on the pricing system. I trust them. They know what they're doing. They've got good tests. And so I wrote it, I've forgotten about it. People come to me at work and go, Andrew, we have a problem with the pricing system, like I wrote that four years ago, I have no idea how it works anymore,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I gave it off to a team, I trusted them, and I've forgotten about it, I have moved to other things.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You have to learn to forget, that's kind of the key part of being a senior or lead software engineer,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you have to trust in that

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: ability to like take a problem, fix it, and maybe trust in yourself, and be trusting somebody else,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: but to just forget about it and make sure that that's the right thing. And occasionally you'd be

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: like we found a bug in it, you would go and remember it all and relearn it again, but that's

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: kind of part of the job. And this kind of underlines a key part of like, when I talk about engineering, people think software engineering is programming. That is wrong.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: In my opinion, the number one skill you can have as a software engineer is communication. Any system

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you are building that is big enough to affect a lot of people is probably bigger than just you,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and at that point, communication is the number one skill. So many people don't do things like contracts or tests. They don't know what other teams are doing in their company. You've got to understand how to split problems out and how to trust other teams with problems, and then make sure that you're talking with them and making sure that your trust is good and their trust in you is good. That's part of the job. Most of my time at work is

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: not writing code. It's going and saying, you should go and talk to this person and you

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: should talk to this person and also, like, basically coordinating people. That's my job

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: now. That's still engineering. My job is, like, making sure everyone's thinking about

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: things right, architecting things the right way, spilling them the right way, but it's not just about running code.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: The wonderful computer scientist Grace Hopper, I love this particular quote,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: A ship in port is safe, but that's not what ships are built for.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And that's kind of the difference between computer science and engineering, and Grace Hopper was both.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: She was a fantastic computer scientist and a fantastic software engineer. And you've got to kind of straddle those two lines, right? Like

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: computer science is all about doing things perfectly and validating them and performing well.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Computer engineering is about the real world and making them quickly and dirty and testing them and

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: getting there eventually. And you've got to kind of expect both of them. One of the things you're

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: going to do is you're going to build to expect growth, right? And I don't mean growth and scaling. I don't mean traffic. I don't mean users. I mean code base and code size growth. When you write software, like when I write software now, I already immediately put things into modules. I'm like, okay, this is where the tests go. This is where my image processing goes. This is where this goes. Because I'm not planning even to have a team on this. I'm planning,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I know that I will forget some of this at some point. I'm planning for my future self.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: I'm planning to forget, I'm planning to scale up my knowledge of the system. That's kind

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of what you could go into these problems doing. But you've also, as I said earlier, you've

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: got to build to expect failure. You've got to understand that something is going to go wrong. In the world of computer science especially, like there

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: are parts in computer science that do model and handle failure. They're

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: incredible. They take it as part of the theory. They work it in and you can build

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: perfect programs that account for failure. But it takes a long time and

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: there's a balance there between that and the real world. Your job is to work out

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: like what are your most likely failures?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: What is your risks, your attack vectors, if it's a security problem, right?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Is it power outages?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Is it natural disasters?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: For example, like, if all your data is stored in a single location, and that location is,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: say, San Francisco, California, congratulations, it's one of the biggest earthquake zones in

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the world, I'm sure it's very safe forever, definitely not going to go wrong there. You have to kind of understand those threat models. There are some places in the world that are chosen for backup locations because they're very, very boring. There's nothing there, like well, there's no cities, there's no earthquakes, there's no volcanoes, it's far away from the sea, Like, it would take a disaster of epic proportions to affect this. That's kind of part of their thinking.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But it's more than just that. Like, even in normal cases, like, power outages is the number one thing. Network is the second thing. Think of those at least.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: But also know that you can build near-perfect software. You can build software that acts basically, you know, to a level of perfection

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: that no human would ever notice a difference. All of you can do this, given enough time. The one,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: the thing about software engineering is, given enough time, you can do anything. You can learn,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: you can improve your skills, you can understand how to build things perfectly.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: The problem is, should you, right? Like, you've got to know when not to do that.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, when do you take the time, sit down, do the three hours of work, and write the tests, or write the proof, or reason about it, or find the right algorithm?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Or when do you just go, ah, and just stick it out and code it quickly?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: You've got to know when to balance these two things. One of the reasons I love Python,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: and I'm still doing Python after 15 years,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: is it lets you do both.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Python is an incredible language

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: for doing both of these particular problems.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And it's even got better at that over time.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Like, when Python was young,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it was much more of a quick, dirty scripting language

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: of like, oh, you want to replace Perl, basically.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Over time, as big companies have grown up and used Python, they've affected it in the add of these things that make it much more useful for real work and making programs that run well. Three examples here, types, async, and speed. And this is kind of how I think you should approach these particular problems in Python. First of all, typing in Python. Typing in Python is strong but dynamic, right?

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Variables don't have fixed types. Except you can now with MyPy. And what the nice thing

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: here is, you can start your code quickly, you can make a prototype. Python is amazing

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: at prototypes. Like you try writing a quick thing in Rust, it will take you like three

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: days. Like the types are wrong still. Are days. The types are wrong. The service call is wrong. Python will happily ignore most of your problems. It kind of knows. It will ignore them and let you run it mostly anyway. And then later on, you can go in and add types where you need them. In the login code, in the security code, in the money code, there we're going to add types and tests more, and then we're

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: going to not have them everywhere else. You can choose where to put your effort where

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: it's used best. Python is really good at that. MyPy is a typing solution that comes along

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: with that because there's nothing better for finding out if you can do a thing than writing

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: a prototype. But too many prototypes make it to production because the cost of rewriting one is very, very high. The ability to take a thing and then add types and add things gradually is super, super amazing.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Asynchronous code. People come to me and go, Andrew, I want to write everything async. Where do I start? I'm like, first, don't write everything async. It's a terrible idea. Don't do it. I don't do it because it's very confusing.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: idea, don't do it. I don't do it because it's very confusing. If you've ever tried to write asynchronous code, you were quickly into a giant piece of paper with lines, like some

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: kind of maths, like diagram, like red string, like what goes over here. It's very, very

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: complicated. What you should do is make it work synchronously first and then work out

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: what would benefit from async. Like, oh, here we're calling four websites at once,

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: or those we can simplify and do them in parallel.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Here, we are doing an algorithm that we parallelize.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Great, the algorithm we can parallelize.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020 [862xL6jm_PQ].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: And like, add it progressively.

title: Andrew Godwin - Keynote - PyCon Colombia 2020

text: That's good. Good advice. You're currently working in social sprouts. Can you tell us more about what do you do in your work?

title: Interview Lorena Mesa  - Keynote Speaker - PyCon Colombia 2018
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Lorena Mesa  - Keynote Speaker - PyCon Colombia 2018 [OHzhNr2_Cpc].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Yeah, yeah. So my company is based in Chicago. We now have an office in Seattle. So Sprout Social is essentially what we do.

title: Interview Lorena Mesa  - Keynote Speaker - PyCon Colombia 2018
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Interview Lorena Mesa  - Keynote Speaker - PyCon Colombia 2018 [OHzhNr2_Cpc].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: We are a software that pairs with Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus. And what we offer is an ability for brands or companies to actually have a streamlined inbox. So rather than having to go to all these platforms natively, they can go ahead and go to one place, curate their content, get analytics, and actually, for example, you'll notice social media is on the rise. You know, 2005, no one's using it. You start looking at now, you have, I don't have the stats off the top of my head, but you know, we're going to be bringing the next billion people online, which is a global audience in Africa and parts of South America over the next three to five years, I believe it is. That's a huge market. And that's kind of where we want to be with social, is enabling brands from your local, your local mom and pop shop to something like Hilton to be able to engage with their audience.

author: PyCon Colombia
text: You need to be persistent. You need to keep trying. You need to do little things over and over again.

title: Interview Russel Keith Magee - Keynote Speaker - PyCon Colombia 2019

author: PyCon Colombia

author: PyCon Colombia
text: what is supposed to be used for? It's very common for projects to be created for a very specific thing, and then with time they evolve and they end up doing something completely different.

title: Flavio Percoco - Inheriting code, and I don't mean classes - PyCon Colombia 2020
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Flavio Percoco - Inheriting code, and I don't mean classes - PyCon Colombia 2020 [3zDNMiHmVmI].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: Or it's also very common that you write a project to do something very specific, and then your users find out that they can also use your project for something completely different, and they end up doing that. Now, you might not have thought about developing the project to actually surface that use case as well, but that has become a use case of your project, and you have to decide whether that is something that you want to support, or that is something that you want to advise your users against. What is adoption? You want to know how many users you have, how many people are using the project. And this is a, like knowing what adoption the project has, it helps when it comes to deciding what kind of changes you want to make to the project. If you want to make a change, then the change is a breaking change. If you know how many users and what the adoption of your project is, you at least know how many users are going to be impacted

text: less dangerous, because remember, you're new to this code base. You're starting to make changes to it. If you do a bunch of fruit writes, you might be changing something that you don't know that some other part of the software actually needs. If you isolate the changes that you're making, then it's going to be easier for you to actually figure out when something breaks, like, aha, it broke when I did this change, so there's probably something here. Now, if you fix a bug and then you refactor the whole thing in the same change, you have no freaking idea what's happening, right? So you have to revert the whole thing, then split it, and break it down as like, ah, my man. All right, focus on progress, not perfection. Super important, super hard to do. Because we like to call ourselves perfectionists,

text: as a final note, I think, as there's this analogy of not taking the shortest path, but aim for the fastest, even if it is, you know, longer than a short one. So the analogy goes, if you are, if you're in a city and you're in point A and you have to go to point B, probably the shortest path is just to cut down downtown and go straight to point B, right? You go from north to south, you cut through the city, drive through downtown, but that, like, that is the shortest path, but that doesn't necessarily is the fastest one, right? But that turns out, like, if you go to the left, and you go around the city, you're going to be driving for, like, an extra 20 miles, but it's actually faster because you can hit the highway and then hit the gas and then you get to the point way faster, right? So the whole point here is that it can be really tempting when you're giving these books

text: Entonces, eso nos lleva al tema de esta charla, que es que hacer Machine Learning es hacer software. Así que los principios, los principios de software engineering común y silvestre, aplican igual. Entonces, pero además, entonces además de lo normal, hay otras prácticas de software engineering que hay que adoptar específicamente para resolver la pasa que es machine learning. Y acá la spoiler es que claro que sí, aunque en algunos lugares no tanto como parecen. La agenda de la charla es revisar algunas prácticas y herramientas de software engineering, dado que lo inmenso del tema y el tiempo disponible no voy a hacer exactivo, sino que voy a ir mostrando ejemplos y mi objetivo va a ser generar interés por estos temas para que luego cada uno pueda profundizar. A grosso modo, voy a partir en tres bloques, voy a hablar de herramientas y prácticas de desarrollo, herramientas y prácticas de planning y gestión, y herramientas tecnológicas que aportan el software engineering de Machine Learning.

text: Y que de por sí esa parte no es muy incierta, porque está súper estudiada. En realidad, todo lo que queda es la incertidumbre que viene de la parte específica que es de Machine Learning. Entonces, mirando esa parte, las preguntas que aparecen son, ¿es factible construir esa parte? ¿Puedo construir un modelo? ¿Se puede resolver? ¿O qué calidad predictiva vamos a lograr alcanzar? ¿O en cuántos meses podemos llegar a producción? Y etcétera. Hay muchas de esas preguntas. Tener buenas herramientas para atacar estas preguntas es lo que consideramos dentro de Software Engineering para Planning y Gestión.

title: Rafael Carrascosa - Software engineering for machine learning at Mercado Libre

author: PyCon Colombia
text: El primero es la herramienta de factibilidad humana, una de nuestras preferidas, pero apoya una pregunta que es muy simple para hablar de factibilidad, que es la tarea de machine learning. La puede hacer una persona? Si la respuesta es que sí, que una persona puede resolver la misma tarea con acceso a la misma información, entonces. Es muy probable que un sistema de machine learning también pueda hacerlo. Ahora mucho más interesante todavía, si una persona no puede hacer una tarea, entonces es extremadamente improbable que un sistema machine lo pueda hacer. Por supuesto que si alguien en la audiencia ahora se pone a buscar un caso extremo, va a encontrar el caso donde esta regla no aplica, pero es un excelente rule of thumb. Entonces, siguiendo con esta idea, un corralario de la factibilidad humana que tal vez es para mí más interesante, es que si dos personas no se pueden poner de acuerdo en una tarea, entonces un sistema de machine learning tampoco.

title: Rafael Carrascosa - Software engineering for machine learning at Mercado Libre
path: PyCon-co audios/audios/Rafael Carrascosa - Software engineering for machine learning at Mercado Libre [OVe1GzubDP8].mp3
author: PyCon Colombia
text: O sea que el acuerdo entre jueces en un dataset de alguna manera aproxima una cuota superior a la performance del sistema de Machine Learning. Y acá, si quieren jugar con esto, es súper divertido. Los invito a que en sus equipos, en sus oficinas, como compañeros de trabajo, se busquen algunas fotos de algún tema y traten de clasificar y ponerse de acuerdo. Van a notar que si la tarea es medianamente no trivial, no se ponen de acuerdo. Entonces ahora avanzando a la herramienta número dos, de las dos que dije que iba a mencionar, la otra es, tal vez un poco abstracta, es difícil de atrapar pero muy poderosa. Se engaña, es simple, pero engaña. Es el tradeoff entre la calidad y el tiempo. Para explicar esta herramienta, voy a agarrar un ejemplo que sería como un típico sistema de moderación. Acá, digamos que, tenemos que moderar la venta de medicamentos en mercado libre. O sea, no se pueden vender antibióticos, por ejemplo, en mercado libre o algo que tenga el riesgo de ser más fármaco. En este sistema, los títulos de los productos pasan por un sistema de Machine Learning que realiza algunas moderaciones de manera automática y algunas decisiones difíciles las deriva un humano para que modelen. Este sistema que es super tradicional, super clásico, contempla y acepta que la parte que hace Machine Learning cometa errores. Y que todo va a seguir funcionando aunque esa parte cometa errores. O sea, que si un sistema de Machine Learning tuviera la calidad predictiva super mala, el sistema entero no estaría roto, sino que los sumos sería caro porque necesitaría muchos humanos que le estuvieran llevando mucho trabajo, o sería de mala calidad para los usuarios de nuestro marketplace. Dicho de otra forma, la calidad de las predicciones es un requerimiento no funcional del sistema. Les pido que se agarren un segundo esa idea mientras avanzo a los filmes siguientes. La otra parte es que hay un enorme abanico de soluciones para resolver un sistema de machine learning, para el modelado, un sistema que hace predicciones. Por ejemplo, volviendo a la modelación de medicamentos, en un extremo, yo podría programar esta función que está en pantalla en solo un minuto, tener alguna predicción de mi sistema.

text: Hablando de propiedades, acá no voy a estar diciendo nada que sea revolucionario, sino simplemente voy a estar dándole entidad, nombre y apellido a las cosas que todos ya sabemos de alguna manera. La primera propiedad que voy a mencionar es que el software tradicional tiene el código fuente como artefacto principal, es lo que uno produce, es el que el producto entiende dando vueltas. En Machine Learning aparece el modelo, o sea que es el binario que tiene los parámetros de nuestro modelo en sí, como artefacto principal también. Se suma un artefacto central. Entonces, esto habilita algunas discusiones como, por ejemplo, si para el código tenemos Git y el modelo es tan artefacto principal como el código, ¿deberíamos tener un Git para modelos? La verdad que no sé, pero lo relevante de acá es que darle esa entidad al modelo o al artefacto este que se acaba de sumar, es que nos hace pensar en qué soporte de ingeniería le damos a un artefacto que es tan importante como código. Esa es la pregunta central, ¿no? Lo de Git era solo un disparado. La segunda propiedad es que aparece un flujo de trabajo que es completamente distinto, nuevo, y es el flujo de entrenamiento.
